name: Lemon Balm
climate: Lemon Balm thrives in temperate to warm climates with mild summers.
It prefers regions that do not experience extremes in temperature.
Ideal climate includes Mediterranean-like areas with seasonal rainfall.
The plant does well in USDA Hardiness Zones 4 to 9, enduring mild frost.
sunlight: Lemon Balm grows best in full sun areas receiving at least six hours daily.
It can tolerate partial shade, especially in very hot climates.
Too much shade may lead to leggy growth and reduced leaf production.
Full sun provides the energy needed for the plant's aromatic oils.
watering: Lemon Balm should be watered regularly but avoid overwatering.
Keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged for best growth.
Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings.
Reduce watering frequency in cooler months to prevent root rot.
soil: Lemon Balm prefers rich, well-draining soil with a neutral pH level.
A loamy soil enriched with organic matter supports healthy growth.
Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent root diseases.
Use compost or well-rotted manure to enhance soil fertility and structure.
extra_care_tip: Regularly pinch back growing tips to keep Lemon Balm bushy and compact.
This plant can become invasive; regular trimming helps control its spread.
Cut back plants after flowering to encourage fresh, vigorous growth.
Mulch around the plant base to retain soil moisture and suppress weeds.
